content: quote: Medvedev Pushes Plan to Remake Russian Military Russian President Dmitry Medvedev vowed to press ahead with an ambitious overhaul of Russia’s armed forces despite the nation’s economic problems and vocal opposition from within the military. Medvedev promised weapons upgrades but also endorsed organizational changes that will cut the officer corps by more than half, or as many as 200,000 positions. The plan, first disclosed in October, envisions the most dramatic transformation of the Russian military since World War II, abandoning a structure designed to mobilize large numbers of new troops to fight a major war and replacing it with a leaner, standing army that can respond more quickly to local conflicts. Thousands of combat units now staffed only with officers would be eliminated, and the military’s four-level command structure would be trimmed to a three-tier hierarchy. (Washington Post, March 18, 2009, Pg. 8)

content: quote: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates played down the risk of new military challenges to the U.S. from its two former Cold War adversaries — Russia and China. A day after Russian President Dmitry Medvedev announced that Russia would rearm its military and boost its nuclear forces, the U.S. defense chief said Moscow is actually moving to reduce the size of its traditional military force. Gates told reporters at a Pentagon briefing he also does not believe aggressive Chinese behavior against U.S. Navy surveillance vessels in the South China Sea suggests Beijing wants to force the U.S. Pacific fleet from the region. (Reuters.com, March 18, 2009)

content: reducing the size of the military to a manageable and professional level will save the Military as much as US8 billion per year and thats no small potatoes in Russia. Modern weapons systems and communications integration are central to this plan. The ability to do more with less has been an Achilles heel for the Russian military that has traditionally relied upon massive and overwhelming numbers instead of tactical skill and battlefield management. It literally takes 10 Russian soldiers to do what 5 American ones can do in terms of training and mission capability.
